types.name: Avatar
types.description:
An __Avatar__ (also known as a profile picture or userpic) is a graphical
representation of a user or the user's character or persona.

types.name: BackwardPageInput
types.description:
Enable backward pagination, slicing can be done with *last*. The *before* is a
opaque cursor returned by *pageInfo*'s *startCursor* node

inputFields.name: before
inputFields.description: number of the page or last edges before this cursor

types.name: BigInt
types.description: The `BigInt` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values.

types.name: Boolean
types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.

types.name: Byte
types.description: The `Byte` scalar type represents byte value as a Buffer

types.name: Connection
types.description:
*Connection* is in compliance with
[*GraphQL Cursor Connections Specification*
](https://relay.dev/graphql/connections.htm#sec-Connection-Types)
to consistenly handle pagination best practices with support for slicing
and *metadata* about the
connection itself

fields.name: edges
fields.description: relationship between two node on the graph

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: additional information about the connection itself

types.name: CreateThreadResponse
types.description: Response object for creating threads

fields.name: thread
fields.description: created thread when the operation is a success

types.name: Currency
types.description: A field whose value is a Currency: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217.

types.name: Cursor
types.description: The Cursor is an opaque string in base64 encoding used by connection pattern to navigate between pages

types.name: DID
types.description: A field whose value conforms to the standard DID format as specified in did-core: https://www.w3.org/TR/did-core/.

types.name: Date
types.description: A date string, such as 2007-12-03, compliant with the `full-date` format outlined in section 5.6 of the RFC 3339 profile of the ISO 8601 standard for representation of dates and times using the Gregorian calendar.

types.name: DateTime
types.description: A date-time string at UTC, such as 2007-12-03T10:15:30Z, compliant with the `date-time` format outlined in section 5.6 of the RFC 3339 profile of the ISO 8601 standard for representation of dates and times using the Gregorian calendar.

types.name: Duration
types.description:
A string representing a duration conforming to the ISO8601 standard,
such as: P1W1DT13H23M34S
P is the duration designator (for period) placed at the start of the duration representation.
Y is the year designator that follows the value for the number of years.
M is the month designator that follows the value for the number of months.
W is the week designator that follows the value for the number of weeks.
D is the day designator that follows the value for the number of days.
T is the time designator that precedes the time components of the representation.
H is the hour designator that follows the value for the number of hours.
M is the minute designator that follows the value for the number of minutes.
S is the second designator that follows the value for the number of seconds.

Note the time designator, T, that precedes the time value.

Matches moment.js, Luxon and DateFns implementations
,/. is valid for decimal places and +/- is a valid prefix

types.name: Edge
types.description:
The concept of an [*edge*
](https://relay.dev/graphql/connections.htm#sec-Edge-Types) also proves
useful if there is information that is specific to the edge, rather than to
one node, which means information about a connection instance.

fields.name: cursor
fields.description: Opaque cursor used to navigate through pages

fields.name: node
fields.description:
This field must return either a Scalar, Enum, Object, Interface, Union, or
a Non-Null wrapper around one of those types. Notably, this field cannot
return a list.

types.name: EmailAddress
types.description: A field whose value conforms to the standard internet email address format as specified in RFC822: https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc822/.

types.name: ForwardPageInput
types.description:
Enable forward pagination, slicing can be done with *first*. The *after* is a
opaque cursor returned by **pageInfo**'s **endCursor** node

inputFields.name: after
inputFields.description: number of the page or edges after this cursor

types.name: GUID
types.description: A field whose value is a generic Universally Unique Identifier: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier.

types.name: HSL
types.description: A field whose value is a CSS HSL color: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#hsl()_and_hsla().

types.name: HSLA
types.description: A field whose value is a CSS HSLA color: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#hsl()_and_hsla().

types.name: HexColorCode
types.description: A field whose value is a hex color code: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_colors.

types.name: Hexadecimal
types.description: A field whose value is a hexadecimal: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexadecimal.

types.name: IBAN
types.description: A field whose value is an International Bank Account Number (IBAN): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Bank_Account_Number.

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: IPv4
types.description: A field whose value is a IPv4 address: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4.

types.name: IPv6
types.description: A field whose value is a IPv6 address: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv6.

types.name: ISBN
types.description: A field whose value is a ISBN-10 or ISBN-13 number: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number.

types.name: ISO8601Duration
types.description:
A string representing a duration conforming to the ISO8601 standard,
such as: P1W1DT13H23M34S
P is the duration designator (for period) placed at the start of the duration representation.
Y is the year designator that follows the value for the number of years.
M is the month designator that follows the value for the number of months.
W is the week designator that follows the value for the number of weeks.
D is the day designator that follows the value for the number of days.
T is the time designator that precedes the time components of the representation.
H is the hour designator that follows the value for the number of hours.
M is the minute designator that follows the value for the number of minutes.
S is the second designator that follows the value for the number of seconds.

Note the time designator, T, that precedes the time value.

Matches moment.js, Luxon and DateFns implementations
,/. is valid for decimal places and +/- is a valid prefix

types.name: JSON
types.description: The `JSON` scalar type represents JSON values as specified by [ECMA-404](http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/ECMA-404.pdf).

types.name: JSONObject
types.description: The `JSONObject` scalar type represents JSON objects as specified by [ECMA-404](http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/ECMA-404.pdf).

types.name: JWT
types.description: A field whose value is a JSON Web Token (JWT): https://jwt.io/introduction.

types.name: Latitude
types.description: A field whose value is a valid decimal degrees latitude number (53.471): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latitude

types.name: LocalDate
types.description: A local date string (i.e., with no associated timezone) in `YYYY-MM-DD` format, e.g. `2020-01-01`.

types.name: LocalEndTime
types.description: A local time string (i.e., with no associated timezone) in 24-hr `HH:mm[:ss[.SSS]]` format, e.g. `14:25` or `14:25:06` or `14:25:06.123`.  This scalar is very similar to the `LocalTime`, with the only difference being that `LocalEndTime` also allows `24:00` as a valid value to indicate midnight of the following day.  This is useful when using the scalar to represent the exclusive upper bound of a time block.

types.name: LocalTime
types.description: A local time string (i.e., with no associated timezone) in 24-hr `HH:mm[:ss[.SSS]]` format, e.g. `14:25` or `14:25:06` or `14:25:06.123`.

types.name: Long
types.description: The `BigInt` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values.

types.name: Longitude
types.description: A field whose value is a valid decimal degrees longitude number (53.471): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitude

types.name: MAC
types.description: A field whose value is a IEEE 802 48-bit MAC address: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address.

types.name: MutationResponse
types.description: Mutation response basic object which every mutation return type must implement

fields.name: code
fields.description: response code status, can be HTTP or application specific

fields.name: message
fields.description: message with more details about the operation

fields.name: success
fields.description: indicates whether the operation was a success

types.name: Naming
types.description:
Naming is a way to calling users. Community users must have a nickname but
not necessary it has first or last names specified

fields.name: first
fields.description: user first name

fields.name: last
fields.description: user last name

fields.name: nick
fields.description: user nickname

types.name: NegativeFloat
types.description: Floats that will have a value less than 0.

types.name: NegativeInt
types.description: Integers that will have a value less than 0.

types.name: Node
types.description: Regular node which is returned by Edge type, it must have at least ID type

types.name: NonEmptyString
types.description: A string that cannot be passed as an empty value

types.name: NonNegativeFloat
types.description: Floats that will have a value of 0 or more.

types.name: NonNegativeInt
types.description: Integers that will have a value of 0 or more.

types.name: NonPositiveFloat
types.description: Floats that will have a value of 0 or less.

types.name: NonPositiveInt
types.description: Integers that will have a value of 0 or less.

types.name: ObjectID
types.description: A field whose value conforms with the standard mongodb object ID as described here: https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/method/ObjectId/#ObjectId. Example: 5e5677d71bdc2ae76344968c

types.name: PageInfo
types.description:
[**PageInfo**
](https://relay.dev/graphql/connections.htm#sec-undefined.PageInfo)
is metadata information about **Connection** used to navigate providing
intel about more previous or next pages. For example, *endCursor* can be used
in to forwarding pagination argument

fields.name: endCursor
fields.description: corresponds the last node, also known as the last connection's edge

fields.name: hasNextPage
fields.description:
indicate whether more edges exist following the set defined by the clients
arguments

fields.name: hasPreviousPage
fields.description:
indicate whether more edges exist prior to the set defined by the clients
arguments

fields.name: startCursor
fields.description: corresponds the last node, also known as the first connection's edge

types.name: PageInput
types.description:
Enable forward and backward pagination, slicing can be done with *first*
and *last*. Opaque cursor is defined by *after* and *before* returned by
**pageInfo**'s **endCursor** and *startCursor* node respectively.

inputFields.name: after
inputFields.description: number of the page or edges after this cursor

inputFields.name: before
inputFields.description: number of the page or last edges before this cursor

types.name: PhoneNumber
types.description: A field whose value conforms to the standard E.164 format as specified in: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E.164. Basically this is +17895551234.

types.name: Port
types.description: A field whose value is a valid TCP port within the range of 0 to 65535: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_Control_Protocol#TCP_ports

types.name: PositiveFloat
types.description: Floats that will have a value greater than 0.

types.name: PositiveInt
types.description: Integers that will have a value greater than 0.

types.name: Post
types.description:
An *Post* is an user-submitted message enclosed into a block containing the
user's details and the date and time it was submitted. Posts are contained in
threads, where they appear as blocks one after another. The first post starts
the thread; this may be called the OP (original post). Posts that follow in
the thread are meant to continue discussion about that post, or respond to
other replies; it is not uncommon for discussions to be derailed.

fields.name: author
fields.description: post's author

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: post' creation time

fields.name: id
fields.description: post identifier

fields.name: likes
fields.description: amount of users who liked the post

fields.name: message
fields.description: summarize the discussion proposed, detailed information about a topic

fields.name: replies
fields.description: posts which replies to this one

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: post' last update time

types.name: PostParticipantsConnection
types.description:
The **PostParticipantsConnection** represents an endpoint of an edge. It
defines **totalCount** metadata to count the number of distinct users

fields.name: edges
fields.description: user' edges

fields.name: interactions
fields.description: total number of post's participants edges

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: page information

types.name: PostParticipantsEdge
types.description:
The **PostParticipantsEdge** is a connection between two nodes, each user
edge endpoint doens't have any metadata and returns simple User node

fields.name: cursor
fields.description: user's edge cursor

fields.name: node
fields.description: node is a plain User type

types.name: PostRepliesConnection
types.description:
**PostRepliesConnection** represents self relationship between posts
indicading a reply. A post can be a reply of another posts

fields.name: edges
fields.description: post's edges

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: page information

types.name: PostReplyEdge
types.description:
**PostReplyEdge** implements Edge's connection pattern, representing an
endpoint from a relationship in any direction

fields.name: cursor
fields.description: post's cursor

fields.name: node
fields.description: node presents a simple post

types.name: PostalCode
types.description: A field whose value conforms to the standard postal code formats for United States, United Kingdom, Germany, Canada, France, Italy, Australia, Netherlands, Spain, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium, India, Austria, Portugal, Switzerland or Luxembourg.

fields.name: threads
fields.description:
Get a list of all threads (also known as original posts), that's a thread
starter which originates a conversation. That list represents all top-level
posts which can be paginated by the user

types.name: RGB
types.description: A field whose value is a CSS RGB color: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#rgb()_and_rgba().

types.name: RGBA
types.description: A field whose value is a CSS RGBA color: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#rgb()_and_rgba().

types.name: SafeInt
types.description: The `SafeInt` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values that are considered safe as defined by the ECMAScript specification.

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: Thread
types.description:
A thread (sometimes called a topic) is a collection of posts, although this
is typically configurable: Options for newest to oldest and for a threaded
view (a tree-like view applying logical reply structure before chronological
order) can be available. A thread is defined by a title and an opening post
(common abbreviation OP, which can also be used to refer to the original
poster), which opens whatever dialogue or makes whatever announcement the
poster wished. A thread can contain any number of posts, including multiple
posts from the same members, even if they are one after the other.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: creation time

fields.name: lastActivity
fields.description: newest reply

fields.name: participants
fields.description:
all unique participants of the thread, which means all its op's replies
and its entire subtree

fields.name: post
fields.description: Original post of the thread, also known as thread starter

fields.name: replies
fields.description: quantity of replies under original post

fields.name: title
fields.description:
A brief introduction to the discussion, it intends to engage people around
a conversation

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: last update time

types.name: ThreadConnection
types.description:
Thread connection implements Connection defining edges, pageInfo and has the
total number of threads in the community. The total number of threads refers
to the quantity of raised topics, or beginning of an conversation

fields.name: edges
fields.description: connections between thread and posts

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: additional information about the pagination

fields.name: total
fields.description: number of threads in total

types.name: ThreadEdge
types.description: Thread edge implements Edge defining node and cursor but has specific metadata

fields.name: cursor
fields.description: opaque cursor

fields.name: node
fields.description: node is a simple thread

types.name: Time
types.description: A time string at UTC, such as 10:15:30Z, compliant with the `full-time` format outlined in section 5.6 of the RFC 3339profile of the ISO 8601 standard for representation of dates and times using the Gregorian calendar.

types.name: Timestamp
types.description: The javascript `Date` as integer. Type represents date and time as number of milliseconds from start of UNIX epoch.

types.name: Timestamps
types.description:
The **Timestamps** is metadata information about a particular object. It
tells when it was created and last updated. Notice: updatedAt doesn't store
historical data only the last update date

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: create date and time

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: last update date and time

types.name: URL
types.description: A field whose value conforms to the standard URL format as specified in RFC3986: https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3986.txt.

types.name: USCurrency
types.description: A currency string, such as $21.25

types.name: UUID
types.description: A field whose value is a generic Universally Unique Identifier: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier.

types.name: UnsignedFloat
types.description: Floats that will have a value of 0 or more.

types.name: UnsignedInt
types.description: Integers that will have a value of 0 or more.

types.name: User
types.description:
Refers to utilizers of the system. At first people can initiate an
*original post (OP)*, beginning a topic or just join a conversation through
posting in the threads. Users in this system are used to provide customized
experience in the application. They aren't tracked in any form

fields.name: avatar
fields.description: user avatar, a image representing its persona

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: creation date and time

fields.name: id
fields.description: user identifier

fields.name: name
fields.description: user names

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: last update date and time

types.name: UtcOffset
types.description: A field whose value is a UTC Offset: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones

types.name: Void
types.description: Represents NULL values

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name, description and optional `specifiedByUrl`, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields`, `interfaces`, and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted using the Markdown syntax, as specified by [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org/).

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

directives.name: specifiedBy
directives.description: Exposes a URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.

args.name: url
args.description: The URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.
